title: Erme Plym Trail Walking Route

images.title: jeff collins / Erme Plym Trail, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: This part of the trail is just after Yeolands,heading towards Lower Keaton.

images.title: Derek Harper / Erme-Plym trail, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The trail leaves the A379 via this stile and crosses a field, not using a public right of way as such. On the left, a track curves towards Sequer's Bridge Quarry.

images.title: Derek Harper / Gates on the Erme-Plym Trail, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Gates on the Erme-Plym Trail The trail passes through the left-hand gate. The right-hand gate leads into a field shaped like a harp.

images.title: Derek Harper / Notice by the Erme-Plym Trail, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Dog Notice by the Erme-Plym Trail

images.title: Derek Harper / Old barn by the Erme-Plym Trail, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Old barn by the trail. Left of centre, a small derelict barn has developed a rounded crown of ivy. Seen from the Erme-Plym Trail as it follows the flood plain of the River Erme downstream.

images.title: Derek Harper / Gate near Modbury Cross, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Gate near Modbury Cross By a track followed by Holbeton Bridleway 5. The Erme-Plym Trail leaves the bridleway to cross this field a metre or two to the left of the gate.

images.title: Derek Harper / Meadow by the Erme-Plym Trail, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Meadow by the trail. Looking through a fringe of trees and across a ditch that borders the trail. This irregularly-shaped field is surrounded by drains. In the distance rises Ugborough Beacon.

images.title: Martin Bodman / Brixton: village edge, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Brixton: village edge, by Footpath 10 which enters the village at the end of Woodland Drive, a mix of Cornish units and more recent housing

description: Follow the Erme - Plym trail from Ivybridge to Laira Bridge on the outskirts of Plymouth on this pleasant walk through Devon. The route runs for about 17 miles on fairly flat paths with fine views over the Dartmoor National Park. You start on the River Erme in Ivybridge and follow the river to south Ermington before heading west to Yealmpton via Flete and Butland Wood. The route continues through Brixton and Combe before arriving at the outskirts at Plymouth where you will pass the lovely Hooe Lake before finishing on Laira Bridge over the River Plym.
